# Descriptive Statistics in Agriculture ðŸ“Š

This week we'll explore how to summarize and visualize agricultural data.

## Load Required Libraries

```{r setup}
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
```

## Load Sample Data

```{r load_data}
# Load our agricultural dataset
crop_data <- read.csv("fertilizer_trial.csv")
head(crop_data)
```

## Measures of Central Tendency

```{r central_tendency}
# Calculate mean, median, and mode for wheat yields
wheat_data <- crop_data[crop_data$crop == "wheat", ]

# Mean
mean_yield <- mean(wheat_data$yield)
cat("Mean wheat yield:", mean_yield, "tons/ha\n")

# Median
median_yield <- median(wheat_data$yield)
cat("Median wheat yield:", median_yield, "tons/ha\n")

# Standard deviation
sd_yield <- sd(wheat_data$yield)
cat("Standard deviation:", sd_yield, "tons/ha\n")
```

## Data Visualization

```{r visualization}
# Create a boxplot comparing different fertilizer treatments
ggplot(crop_data, aes(x = fertilizer, y = yield, fill = fertilizer)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Crop Yield by Fertilizer Type",
       x = "Fertilizer Treatment",
       y = "Yield (tons/ha)") +
  theme_minimal()
```

## Your Turn: Analyze the Data! ðŸŒ±

```{r exercise}
# Calculate summary statistics for each fertilizer treatment
# Hint: Use group_by() and summarise()

summary_stats <- crop_data %>%
  group_by(fertilizer) %>%
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    mean_yield = mean(yield),
    sd_yield = sd(yield),
    min_yield = min(yield),
    max_yield = max(yield)
  )

summary_stats
```
